journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Novel chiral poly(amide-imide) nanocomposites reinforced with silicate layers and TiO2 nanoparticles based on N-trimellitylimido-l-isoleucine

article-meta.aff: 1Organic Polymer Chemistry Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Islamic Republic of Iran
2Nanotechnology and Advanced Materials Institute, Isfahan University of Technology, Islamic Republic of Iran

author-notes.corresp: Shadpour Mallakpour, Organic Polymer Chemistry Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan 84156-83111, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: mallak@cc.iut.ac.ir; mallak777@yahoo.com; mallakpour84@alumni.ufl.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In the present investigation, the goal was the preparation, characterization, and surface morphology of poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposites. At first, an optically active poly(amide-imide) was synthesized from the polymerization reaction of N-trimellitylimido-l-isoleucine diacid with 4,4′-methylenebis(3-chloro-2,6-diethylaniline). The obtained polymer and TiO2 nanoparticles were used to prepare poly(amide-imide)/TiO2 nanocomposites through ultrasonic irradiation. Then, different amounts of organoclay were added to the poly(amide-imide)/TiO2 nanocomposite system to obtain poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposite. The resulting hybrids materials were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, field emission scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis techniques.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer nanocomposites (NCs), composed of organic polymer and inorganic nanoparticles (NPs), have been widely investigated.1,2 When compared to their macrocomposite counterparts, NC materials have significant properties such as modulus, heat-distortion temperature, hardness, strength, dimensional stability, etc.3–5.Polymer NCs that are based on inorganic nanoclay minerals are among the most significant future composite systems. Nanoclays give several properties to the polymer such as: good mechanical and gas barrier properties, thermal stability, and conductivity properties.6–9

Layered silicates are usually hydrophilic and their interactions with non-polar polymers are not favorable.10–12 This problem is resolved by increasing the affinity of organophilic in nanoclay. The organic component of the organoclay, in fact, increases the interaction between the polymer and the ﬁller. Organophilic clay is obtained if the sodium ions are replaced by organic cations, such as alkylammonium ions, alkylphosphonium ions, or protonated amino acids.13–16.Interlayer distance of layered silicates was expanded by the replacement of inorganic exchange ions by organic cations.17,18

Titanium dioxide (TiO2), known as titanium (IV) oxide, exists in three crystalline forms: rutile, anatase, and brookite.19 TiO2, considered as an inert and non-toxic material, has been used in many applications. It was used in solar cells for the production of electric energy, batteries, composites, cosmetics, water decomposition, as a pigment in paints, a corrosion protective coating, and a catalyst.20–24

Poly(amide-imide)s (PAIs) have a positive synergy of properties from both polyamides and polyimides, such as high strength, good solubility in polar amide-type solvent, exceptional high thermal stability, and broad chemical resistance. It is naturally non-flammable, which is a feature of its structure due to high proportion of aromatic structures and double bonds.25 Incorporation of α-amino acid into the polymer structures results in interesting properties including optical activity, solubility in aqueous and highly polar solvents, and electrical conductivity through ion movement. Amino acid based polymers are used in high-performance liquid chromatography for the resolution of enantiomer mixtures, non-linear optics, catalysis, liquid crystals, and biomedical devices. They also have potential biocompatibilities and biodegradability.26,27

Polymerization process in organic solvents has many problems such as air pollution, toxicity, and flammability. Ionic liquids (ILs) can be used to overcome this problem. ILs have been widely promoted as green solvents due to their properties such as chemical stability, low to high viscosity, excellent thermal stability, negligible vapor pressure, cations and anions with different sizes, and high ionic conductivity properties.28–30 ILs dissolves a wide variety of materials including salts, fats, amino acids, surfactants, and polymers.31

In this study, an optically active PAI was prepared by direct polycondensation reaction of diimidedicarboxylic acid containing α-l-isoleucine amino acid and an aromatic diamine using green condition by molten tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB). Due to their non-volatility, ILs have a low impact on the environment and human health and so, they are recognized as green solvents. This PAI, due to the existence of amino acid in their structure, shows potential biodegradability and biocompatibility behavior. High surface energy of NPs is the reason for their strong tendency to agglomerate. For breaking down and better bonding to the polymer matrix, γ-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (KH550) as a coupling agent was used. In the next step, PAI/TiO2 NC (PTNC) containing 10 wt% of NP was prepared under ultrasonic irradiation. Chiral organoclay was synthesized by ion-exchange reaction between Cloisite Na+ and the protonated form of l-isoleucine amino acid. For the preparation of PAI/TiO2/organoclay nanocomposites (PTONCs), different amounts of organoclay (3, 5, 7, and 9 wt%) were added to the PTNC system. The resulting hybrid materials were characterized by a number of techniques.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Solvents and chemicals were obtained from the Aldrich Chemical Co. (Milwaukee, WI, USA), Riedel-deHaen AG (Seelze, Germany), and Merck Chemical Co. (Germany). Sodium montmorillonite (Cloisite Na+) was purchased from Southern Clay Products, Gonzales, TX, USA. The cation-exchange capacity of Cloisite Na+ was 92.6 meq/100 g as reported by suppliers. Trimellitic anhydride, TBAB, and 4,4′-methylenebis(3-chloro-2,6-diethylaniline) were used as obtained without further purification. N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) was dried over BaO and then distilled in vacuum. The coupling agent (3-amino-propyltriethoxysilane; KH550) and l-isoleucine were obtained from Merck Chemical Co. TiO2 NPs with an average particle size of about 30–50 nm was purchased from Nanosabz Co (Iran).

sec.title: Equipment
sec.p: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded (4000–400 cm−1) on a Jasco spectrophotometer (Jasco-680, Japan). Spectra of solids were carried out using KBr pellets. Vibrational transition frequencies are reported in wavenumber (cm−1). Band intensities are assigned as weak (w), medium (m), strong (s), and broad (br). Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H-NMR, 500 MHz) spectra were recorded in dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO-d6) solution using a Bruker (Germany) Avance 500 instrument. Multiplicities of proton resonance were designated as singlet (s), doublet (d) and multiplet (m). Speciﬁc rotation was measured with a Jasco (Osaka, Japan) polarimeter at the concentration of 0.5 g/dL at 25°C. Inherent viscosities were measured by a standard procedure using a Cannon-Fenske Routine Viscometer (Germany). Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) was acquired by HITACHI (S-4160). The reaction was carried out on MISONIX ultrasonic liquid processors, XL-2000 series. Ultrasound was a wave of frequency 2.25 × 104 Hz and power 100 W. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses were performed using a Philips CM 120 operating at 100 kV. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) data were taken on STA503 WinTA instrument in a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 20°C/min and at temperature range 25–800°C. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Philips X’PERT MPD diffractometer (Cu-Kα radiation: λ = 0.154056 nm at 40 kV and 30 mA) over the 2θ range 1.2–10° and 5–100° at a scan rate of 0.05°/min.

sec.title: Synthesis of optically active diacid monomer
sec.p: N-trimellitylimido-l-isoleucine diacid (1) was prepared according to our published article.32

sec.title: Synthesis of polymer and PTNC
sec.p: This PAI was prepared by the following procedure: an equimolar mixture of diacid 1 (0.2 g, 6.55 × 10−4 mol), the aromatic diamine 2 (0.25 g, 6.55 × 10−4 mol), and TBAB (0.84 g, 2.62 × 10−3 mol) was ground until a powder was formed and then it was transferred into a 25 mL flask. Triphenylphosphite (0.7 mL, 2.62 × 10−3 mol) was added to this mixture and the whole solution was stirred at 120°C for 12 h. Then, the viscous solution was precipitated in 30 mL of methanol and filtered and dried to give 0.38 g of PAI (84% yield).The inherent viscosity of the resulting PAI was obtained to be 0.27 dL/g (measured at a concentration of 0.5 g/dL in DMF at 25°C). For the preparation of PTNC, at first, TiO2 NPs were modified with KH550 as the coupling agent and then under ultrasonic radiation, it was dispersed in polymer matrix according to our published article.33

sec.title: Synthesis of organoclay
sec.p: Organo-nanoclay was prepared according to our previous study.15

sec.title: Preparation of PTONCs
sec.p: For the preparation of the PTONCs, at first, PTNC (10 wt%) was dispersed in 2 mL of DMAc at 80°C and then different values of organoclay (3, 5, 7, and 9 wt%) were added to the suspension of PTNC10 wt%. The solution was agitated with mechanical stirrer at 80°C for 2 h and then at 40°C for another 2 h. Then, it was stirred for 8 h at 40°C to form a uniform dispersion of organoclay platelets in suspension of PTNC. Thin film NCs were obtained by pouring the suspension of PTONCs into glass petri dishes and allowing it to dry at 40°C in an oven for 24 h.

sec.title: Preparation of optically active polymer and PTNC hybrid
Modification of NPs
sec.p: The surface-modification of TiO2 NPs was used for increasing the interaction between the NCs and polymeric matrix. Under ultrasonic conditions, hydroxyl forms of KH550 were hydrolyzed to Si–O–Si forms (Scheme 1(a)). Modified NPs, due to hydroxyl groups and organic shell composed of coupling agent on their surface, could be dispersed in polymer matrix via different interactions with the functional groups of PAI. The simple mixing of polymer and layered silicates does not always result in the generation of an NC. This failure is due to the weak interactions between the polymer and the nanoclay. In fact, the organic component of the organoclay increases interactions between the polymer and the filler. The preparation of organoclay involved exchanging an organic ion of amino acid with sodium cations into the galleries of organoclay. Scheme 1(b) shows the schematic of such an adsorption process. By this replacement, d-spacing from 1.17 to 1.45 nm was changed and inter layer was more opened.

sec.title: Fabrication of PTONC
sec.p: An optically active diacid 1 was synthesized by the condensation reaction of an equimolar mixture of dianhydride with chiral l-isoleucine amino acid in acetic acid solution under reflux conditions. Organosoluble and thermally stable PAI3 were synthesized by the direct polycondensation reactions of an equimolar mixture of aromatic diamine 2 with chiral diacid 1 under green condition using molten TBAB (Scheme 2). This polymer showed optical rotation ([α]D25 = 6.36° measured at a concentration of 0.5 g/dL in DMF at 25°C) because of the existing chiral natural amino acid in the polymer backbone. In the next step, PTNC was prepared by the reaction of PAI3 and modified TiO2 NPs under ultrasonic irradiation. Novel optically active PTONCs containing 3, 5, 7, and 9 wt% of organoclay were synthesized by solution intercalation technique. Due to the interaction between organic active groups of organoclay (COOH) with amine of PAI chains, d-space of layers was increased (Scheme 3). Modified nanoclay was homogeneously dispersed in polymer matrix of PTNC system. Owing to the presence of organoclay in these systems, physical and morphological properties were improved.

sec.title: FT-IR spectra
sec.p:
The FT-IR spectra of the organoclay, PTNC, and PTONCs materials are shown in Figure 1. In the spectrum of organoclay (Figure 1(a)), the peak of 3626 cm−1 is attributed to –OH stretching of Al–OH and Si–OH. The broad band at 3440 cm−1 is due to the –OH stretching vibration of interlayer water. The infrared spectrum of the modified clay shows that peaks in the 400–600 cm−1 area that is due to Mg–O and Al–O bending vibration. Bands in the 3500–2800 cm−1 region of isoleucine are mostly observable in the spectrum of the organoclay. FT-IR spectrum of PTNC (10 wt% of TiO2) is shown in Figure 1(b). Absorptions at 1721 and 1777 cm−1 appear due to the symmetrical and asymmetrical carbonyl stretching vibration of imide ring. Absorptions at 1375 and 731 cm−1 correspond to the imide heterocycle ring in these polymers. Absorption peak at 500–800 cm−1 is assigned to the Ti–O–Ti stretching band. In Figure 1(a); bands in the 3000–2900 cm−1 show C–H groups from polymer chain. FT-IR spectrums of PTONCs containing 3, 5, 7, and 9% of organoclay are shown in Figure 3(c) to (f). With increasing of organoclay content, the intensities of organoclay bands become more evident. Figure 1.
FT-IR spectra of organoclay (a), PTNC (b), PTONC 3% (c), PTONC 5% (d), PTONC 7% (e), and PTONC 9% (f).
FT-IR: Fourier transform infrared; PTNC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2 nanocomposite; PTONC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposite.
Figure 3.
XRD curves in the region of 2θ = 1.2–10° of Cloisite Na+ (a), organoclay (b), PTONC 3% (c), PTONC 5% (d), PTONC 7% (e), and PTONC 9% (f).
XRD: X-ray diffraction; PTONC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposite.

sec.title: XRD patterns
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the X-ray patterns of the pure polymer, TiO2 NP, PTNC (10 wt% of TiO2), and PTONC (5 wt% of organoclay) in the region of 2θ = 10–80°. The broad peak in XRD curve of PAI (Figure 2(a)) shows that the PAI in the absence of TiO2 NPs is amorphous, meaning that there are no regular crystalline planes to XRD. Causing a decrease in the crystallinity is due to the reduction of intermolecular forces between polymer chains, which, in turn, is because of the existence of the non-coplanar and twisted units in the polymer structures. Figure 2(b) shows anatase and rutile phase for pure TiO2 NP. XRD curve of PTNC (Figure 2(c)) is similar to XRD pattern of pure TiO2 NP. The average size of the TiO2 NP is calculated from Debye–Scherrer equation, which is approximately 32–35 nm for PTNC. PTONCs were prepared by adding organoclay to the PTNC system. Figure 2(d) shows XRD pattern of the PTONC (5 wt% of organoclay) in the large-angle range. This pattern shows a similar intensity of diffraction of TiO2 due to the existence of anatase and rutile phase in PTONC hybrid, showing that the crystal structure of TiO2 was not altered due to the presence of organoclay. Figure 2.
XRD curves in the region of 2θ = 10–80° of PAI (a), pure TiO2 NPs (b), PTNC (c), and PTONC 5% (d).
XRD: X-ray diffraction; NPs: nanoparticles; PTNC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2 nanocomposite; PTONC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposite; PAI: poly(amide-imide).

The most conventional technique used to analyze the organoclay and polymer/clay NCs is XRD, which measures the interlayer d-spacing. Figure 3 shows XRD patterns of Cloisite Na+, organoclay, and various PTONCs (3, 5, 7, and 9 wt% of organoclay) in the region of 2θ = 1.2–10° and the results are summarized in Table 1. This technique allows the determination of the spaces between structural layers of the silicate utilizing Bragg’s law: sinθ = nλ/2 d, where n is an integer, λ the wavelength of incident wave, d the spacing between the planes in the atomic lattice, and θ the angle between the incident ray and the scattering planes. According to Bragg’s law, in comparison with the spacing of the organoclay used, the intercalation of the polymer chains increases the interlayer spacing, leading to a shift of the diffraction peak toward lower angle.18 The d-spacing of pristine Cloisite Na+ is 1.17 nm and after the ion-exchange reaction with ammonium salt of l-isoleucine amino acid, the peak of the organoclay was shifted to lower angle (2θ = 6.10°, d = 1.45 nm). The presence of 3, 5, and 7 wt% of organoclay in the polymer matrix resulted in a shift to smaller angle 2θ = 1.7–1.8° that corresponds to a d-spacing of 4.90–5.19 nm. XRD pattern of PTONC 9 wt% shows no sharp peaks. The peak shift indicates that the gallery has expanded. It is usually assumed that polymer chains have entered or have been intercalated in the gallery. Table 1.
Basal spacing of Cloisite Na+, organoclay, and PTONCs
Sample 2θ (°) d-spacing (nm)
Cloisite Na+ 7.56 1.17
Organoclay 6.10 1.45
PTONC 3% 1.8 4.90
PTONC 5% 1.7 5.19
PTONC 7% 1.7 5.19
PTONC 9% – –
PTONCs: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposites.

sec.title: Morphology
sec.p:
The morphological images of the PAI3, PTNC, and PTONC (3, 5, 7, and 9 wt% of organoclay) were studied by FE-SEM. The nanoscale morphology of the obtained optically active PAI3 was clearly observed from Figure 4(a) and (b). In the matrix of the PTNC, TiO2 was well dispersed in the polymer. However, Figure 4(c) and (d) shows that the morphology of PAI during the preparation of PTNC was changed. Figure 4(e) to (l) shows the morphology of PTONCs. The results demonstrate which organoclay is homogeneously dispersed in PAI matrix. They also show that the TiO2 NP remained in the structure of polymer. Figure 4.
FE-SEM micrographs of pure PAI (a, b), PTNC (c, d), PTONC 3% (e, f), PTONC 5% (g, h), PTONC 7% (i, j), and PTONC 9% (k, l).
FE-SEM: field emission scanning electron microscopy; PTNC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2 nanocomposite; PTONC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposite; PAI: poly(amide-imide).

On the other hand, TEM illustrates a qualitative understanding of the internal structure and TiO2 domain sizes. TEM images (Figure 5(a) to (c)) of PTNC show that the dispersion of surface modified TiO2 NPs is good and the NP sizes of TiO2 are about 25–49 nm. Figure 5(d) to (f) also shows the typical TEM image of the PTONC (containing 10 wt% of TiO2 and 9 wt% of organoclay). In these images, the brighter region represents the polymer matrix and the dark narrow stripes represent the stacked and intercalated stacked organoclay. Also, these images show that the modified TiO2 NPs were dispersed in polymer matrix and the surface of organoclay. This uniform dispersion is due to the interaction of PAI with NPs and also the electrostatic effect between organoclay and the positively charged titania particles. Figure 5.
TEM images of PTNC (a to c) and PTONC 9% (d to f).
PTNC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2 nanocomposite; PTONC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposite; TEM: transmission electron microscopy.

sec.title: Thermal properties
sec.p:
TGA is a useful tool for rapid assessment of the thermal stability of materials. The TGA curves of PTNC and PTONCs are shown in Figure 6. Data for the thermal degradation of the NCs, including the temperature of T5 and T10 (temperature based on 5% and 10% weight loss), char yield (CR) at 800°C, and also limiting oxygen index (LOI) accordance with Van Krevelen and Hoftyzer equation34 are summarized in Table 2. LOI=17.5+0.4CR Figure 6.
TGA thermograms of PTNC and PTONC under a nitrogen atmosphere at heating rate of 20°C/min.
TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; PTNC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2 nanocomposite; PTONC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposite.
Scheme 1.
Fabrication of modified TiO2 (a) and organoclay (b). Scheme 2.
Synthesis of PAI3.
PAI: poly(amide-imide). Scheme 3.
Preparation of PTONC.
PTONC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposite.
Table 2.
Thermal properties of PTNC and PTONCs
Sample Decomposition temperature (°C) Char yieldb (%) LOIc
T5a T10a
PTNC 246 298 40.1 33.1
PTONC 3% 268 307 42.3 33.9
PTONC 5% 283 321 43.9 34.6
PTONC 7% 296 334 45.6 35.3
PTONC 9% 312 368 47.6 36.1
PTNC: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2 nanocomposite; PTONCs: poly(amide-imide)/TiO2/oganoclay nanocomposites; TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; LOI: limiting oxygen index. a
Temperature at which 5% and 10% weight loss was recorded by TGA at heating rate of 20°C/min in a N2 atmosphere. b
Percentage weight of material left undercomposed after TGA analysis at maximum temperature 800°C in a nitrogen atmosphere. c
LOI evaluated at char yield at 800°C.

The 10% weight loss temperatures of the PTONCs with different organoclay contents (3, 5, 7, and 9 wt%) are about 307–368°C because the organoclays have high thermal stability. The PTONCs have LOI values around 34–36 that were calculated from their char yield at 800°C. On the basis of LOI values, all NCs can be classified as self-extinguishing NCs. The incorporation of organoclay can improve the thermal decomposition rate of PTONC as compared to PTNC.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The PTNC NC was synthesized under ultrasonic irradiation after different amounts of the silica NPs were modified by protonated amino acid and added to the PTNC system via solution intercalation method to obtain PTONC. In fact, protonated amino acid increased the interaction between the polymer and the nanoclay. Layered silicates are usually hydrophilic and their interactions with non-polar polymers are not favorable. This problem is resolved by increasing the affinity of organophilic in nanoclay by the replacement of inorganic exchange ions by organic cations. In this study, positively charged amino acid was chosen to replace the chemically synthesized surfactant for the modification of clay. This molecule has two functional groups of amine, and acid in which the amine is protonated and is attached to the surface of the Cloisite Na+ while the acidic group is free to participate in the polymerization reaction. XRD pattern showed that the distance between the layers for the NCs was increased more than cloisite Na+ and organoclay. FE-SEM and TEM images of PTONCs showed that TiO2 NPs and organoclay were dispersed homogeneously into the PAI matrix, demonstrating that most of the organoclay layers were intercalated. Thermal stability of PTONCs was increased as compared with PTNC hybrid by increasing organoclay content. PTONCs exhibited high thermal stability with decomposition temperature at the range 307–368°C due to the presence of TiO2 NPs and organoclay in polymer matrix, which increased the stability of the polymers toward heating. Due to the presence of amino acids in both organoclay and the polymer backbone, these NCs could show the potential biodegradability behavior.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors express their gratitude to the Research Affairs Division of Isfahan University of Technology (IUT), Isfahan, for partial financial support. Further financial support from Iran nanotechnology Initiative Council, National Elite Foundation, and Center of Excellence in Sensors and Green Chemistry Research (IUT) is gratefully acknowledged.
